author: ConcernedMama  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Dec 01, 2005 3:51 pm Location: Illinois
title: Conflicting FNA and core biopsy
content: I am a 32 y/o lactating woman, no history of family breast cancer. Nine months ago, my baby started sleeping through the night and I woke up laying flat on my right breast and it was red and engorged. I was treated for mastitis and the redness went away, but one month later I was still swollen. I was monitored by a surgeon and finally on 10/12 they performed an FNA (not guided by u/s). It was sent to 2 different pathologists and came back "suggestive of papillary lesion". FNA also classified as "difficult to read due to the presence of air-drying artifact". Core biopsy performed on 11/22 at a well-known breast center took 6 samples of the lump and came back with no abnormalities found and a diagnosis of stromal fibrosis. Ultrasound was consistent with stromal fibrosis and clinical exam was unalarming (thickened tissue and dilated milk ducts).  Surgeon recommends excisional biopsy. Here is the problem: I want to have more children and breastfeed them. I am currently breastfeeding my first child. The lump is subareolar and excision will interfere with future breastfeeding.  Do you know of any alternative to complete surgical excision? Is it possible to overrule the FNA with the core biopsy results since the core biopsy examined so many more cells? I am hesitant to consent to full biopsy unless I have some more evidence that I really need it.
posted_time: Post  by ConcernedMama » Thu Dec 01, 2005 4:05 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope you agreed to do the biopsy. Sometimes the needle and the core biopsies 'miss the target' and take samples from the surrounding tissue rather than from the disease (eg, cancer). Whenever there is a doubt it is best to be sure.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  There are many possible causes for breast pain. These can be broken down into causes related to menstruation (cyclical) or noncyclical pain. Although many women with pain in one or both breasts understandably fear breast cancer, breast pain is NOT a common symptom of cancer.  Common causes of cyclical breast pain include:  Some degree of breast tenderness is normal, caused by hormonal fluctuations. They can be a manifestation of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Fibrocystic breast tissue is a common condition. It involves breast lumps and bumps throughout the breast tissue that tend to be more tender just before your menstrual period.  Noncyclical breast pain can be due to hormonal changes other than those of the menstrual cycle. This includes pregnancy (tends to be more common during the first trimester and pregnancy at a young age); puberty (in both girls and boys); breast feeding; approach of menopause (once your menstrual periods have stopped completely, breast tenderness often goes away unless you are taking hormone replacement therapy) and also soon after childbirth, the breasts may become engorged with milk.  Mastitis from a blocked and infected milk duct, usually associated with breastfeeding; alcoholism with liver damage and injury/ trauma to the breast. Certain medications may also cause breast pain, including digitalis preparations, aldomet, aldactone and other potassium-sparing diuretics, anadrol, and chlorpromazine. Shingles can lead to pain felt in the breast if the painful blistering rash appears on the skin over one of your breasts.  If you are still concerned then you should get it checked out.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat May 13, 2006 2:43 pm

title: breast cancel and birth control pill
content: I'm 35 years old my 31 year old sister was diagnosed with breast cancer this summer. She had a masectomy, chemo and radiation. She also had genetic testing that came up negative for the mutated BRAC 1 - BRAC 2 Gene. I was told to get a mammogram ASAP. I did, a small suspicious mass was found in my right breast, after an Ultra Sound and a needle biopsy were the suspicious 9mm mass was removed it turned out to be benine and diagnosed as Stromal Fibrosis. I actually go tomorrow morning for my 6 months diagnositc mammogram check up, I'm sure I will be monited closely. My question is regarding birh control, I have been on and off the pill for 6 years. I have 2 children and don't plan on having any more, I've even tossed around getting my tubes tighed. I spoke to the gynocologist and was told d that if I wanted to continue to use a low estroggyn based pill as my birth controll that I could stay on it till menapuse. Even the oncologist told me there isnt any hard core evidence that the pill has anything to do with breast cancer, and that some people are put on the pill to avoid cervical cancer. So I guess my question would be is it OK for me to remain on the birth control pill with my history and my sisters history? Thank you for your help. :-)
posted_time: Post  by Maria122 » Wed Jan 04, 2006 3:49 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Your doctors are both correct.  According to the National Cancer Institute, studies examining the use of BCPs as a risk factor for breast cancer have produced inconsistent results. Most studies have not found an overall increased risk for breast cancer associated with oral contraceptive use. For example, in 2002, results from the Women's Contraceptive and Reproductive Experience (Women's CARE) study indicated that present or past use among both Caucasian and African-American women ages 36 to 64 did not significantly increase the risk of breast cancer.  The contraversy surrounds the earlier use of high dose pills in the past.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat May 13, 2006 2:28 pm

Common causes of cyclical breast pain include:  Some degree of breast tenderness is normal, caused by hormonal fluctuations. They can be a manifestation of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  There are many possible causes for breast pain. These can be broken down into causes related to menstruation (cyclical) or noncyclical pain.  Although many women with pain in one or both breasts understandably fear breast cancer, breast pain is NOT a common symptom of cancer.  Boys and men have breast tissue. If a male has breast tissue that is visible, this is called gynecomastia. This can cause pain and tenderness. As a normal part of development, adolescent boys can have some breast swelling and tenderness. Like breast tenderness in women, this is due to hormonal changes.  Common causes of cyclical breast pain include:  Some degree of breast tenderness is normal, caused by hormonal fluctuations. They can be a manifestation of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Fibrocystic breast tissue is a common condition. It involves breast lumps and bumps throughout the breast tissue that tend to be more tender just before your menstrual period.  Noncyclical breast pain can be due to hormonal fluctuations other than those of the menstrual cycle. This includes pregnancy (tends to be more common during the first trimester and pregnancy at a young age); puberty (in both girls and boys); breast feeding; approach of menopause (once your menstrual periods have stopped completely, breast tenderness often goes away unless you are taking hormone replacement therapy) and also soon after childbirth, the breasts may become engorged with milk.  Mastitis from a blocked and infected milk duct, usually associated with breastfeeding; alcoholism with liver damage and injury/ trauma to the breast. Certain medications may also cause breast pain, including digitalis preparations, aldomet, aldactone and other potassium-sparing diuretics, anadrol, and chlorpromazine. Shingles can lead to pain felt in the breast if the painful blistering rash appears on the skin over one of your breasts.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Fri May 12, 2006 4:28 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. Common causes of enlargement include infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma.  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Ultrasound is a useful imaging modality in assessment of lymph nodes.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Tue Mar 07, 2006 11:29 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Please visit our breast risk page. The relative risk of patients with an affected first-degree relative (mother, daughter, or sister) is 1.7 times higher when compared to controls without affected family members.  Depending on the risk you may need to start breast examinations and mammographies at an earlier stage. Prevention strategies for those at very high risk may include tamoxifen, clinical trials or even prophylactic mastectomies in some cases.  Concerning pancreatic cancer it has a very a high mortality rate. Pancreatic cancer is the fifth leading cause of cancer-related death for both men and women (following lung, colon, breast, and prostate cancers) and is responsible for 5% of all cancer-related deaths. Estimated new cases and deaths from pancreatic cancer in the United States in 2005: New cases: 32,180.  Deaths: 31,800.  You can do the calculations when you compare the number of new cases and the number of deaths per year.  Best regards.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi natalielfc, Aside from certain types of breast cancer, other conditions that may cause breast swelling and pain are infection, blocked mammary ducts, fibrocystic changes, etc. However, when swelling occurs (especially unilaterally) and persists, doesn't decrease or change with menstrual cycles, it warrants an investigation by a physician. Pain is an abnormal symptom and indicates that something is malfunctioning regardless of whether its a benign condition or something more serious. Physicians are professionals that treat people in healthy and illness states. Let me ask you, if your children were ill or had complaints of pain would you take them in for an evaluation? Why would you not do the same for yourself? They depend on you to do all in your power to keep yourself healthy to take care of them ;) So, do this for yourself and for them! I strongly suggest that you make an appointment for an evaluation by your physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi winnieelayne, Have you had a recent examination by your physician which  included a breast exam? Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician. The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. Common causes of enlargement include infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma.Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2]. So to answer your question, could this be directly related to your surgery, yes it is not an impossibility. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. If there have been no changes over several months and constitutional symptoms, for example, unintentional weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, etc. are not present it would be less concerning. However, if a recent physical exam (including a breast exam) has not been completed, I would suggest an evaluation to rule out any concerning factor. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN  References: =========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58.  2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: factors affecting your wound healing
content: Dear Fearful,   Yes when i talked about antibiotic resistance i meant that it becomes useless.  One of the possibilities why the wound isn't healing ... 1-Infection in the form of redness, hottness,tenderness,swelling of the wound...does it ooze any form of discharge and what is its colour?...may be you can make a wound swab and see which bacteria is causing the infection and give the appropriate antibiotic according to culture and senstivityof that discharge. 2- a deep wound (is it deep and wide also? and by "wide" i mean that the edges of your skin are not approximating that it might need stitches?) how big is it?  3- low imminuity....Stress decreases the immune system for sure...but not to that extent! ...if you are doing your regular blood tests ,please do a random blood sugar test to make sure you do not have diabetes...which can make you eat a lot,drink alot, pass water a lot,numbness of the fingers....i don't think you have it,but it's just a precaution to be on the safe side,ok?  .  As for what to do...here is my opinion...if there is no infection,the wound is not deep or wide and it's NOT oozing,then just leave it as it is...keep it dry. u don't even have to put a dressing on it....unless ofcourse it's in the way of your bra...u can add a dressing to prevent friction.  I don't think Vaseline is harmful...although i dunno why he's prescribed it...Please describe your wound for me next time.  I will post an article very soon about harmful substances that has been proven to be found in breast tumor cells by molecular biology techniques...so all of us can watch out while buying our skin care products,ok? keep me updated, Best regards

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: skin biopsy result?!
content: Hello Fearful,  well, it's not a big wound ...may be it doesn't heal due to the nature of the disease that's in it ....why did u do a biopsy?! let's get it from the start....and what did the biopsy result show...that might be the answer to your questions!  to keep the wound dry or moist,it's a matter of how it looks like ...I can't really judge something i cannot see... if the wound is deep...then there is something called "granulation tissue formation" which fills in the gap in the wound...then a crust forms on top of it...it's a matter of wound healing stages...it gets longer when the wound is deeper and bigger. we like to keep it dry when a crust forms.  Anyway,let's see why you had a biopsy and what's its result and we'll take it from there, best regards

title: [no title]
content: Dear Fearful,  I think you should stick to one opinion.....i gues it'll be your original dermatologist who did the biopsy....he/she knows how he did the biopsy/why he did it and whether it's healing properly or not.  About the redness, i really can't judge what i cannot see, but like last time ...signs of inflammation includes redness,hotness(compare it to the other breast temperature for an example), tenderness (painfulwhen you press on it), and if there's bacterial infection it almost always oozes a discharge...where its colour depends on the type of bacteria it's harvesting....you can ask for a culture and senstivity test. they take a swab from the wound and determine which bacteria is growing and causing the infection. and to know if that bacteria is a commensal(a bacteria that lives normally on the skin) or a pathogen (causing a bad infection)  i hope i helped...Good luck and don't worry...the most important thing is that the biopsy result is ok    Best regards,

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Fearful,   That's great news:-) ,well, since  the wound has started to fill in...and your dermatologist said there were no signs of infection/inflammation...then we're on the right track.    small and superficial ( in skin not deep) infection causes a slight rise in temperature and it oozes a discharge....and ofcourse inflammation... in the form of red,hot ,swollen and tender wound...which doesn't sound like yours...and by red...i mean redness in an area around the wound margin and it's tender (hurts on touch).  I think your wound is healing in a healthy way...at last! ...redness in your wound means healthy granulation tissue...that fills the gap(like we've talked about it before) . It cannot form a scab as long as you're using vaseline... because it keeps it moist . I think the idea of using vaseline is to make a barrier between the wound and anything else that could interfere in the process of healing..not only infection, but even the friction of your clothes.  If it's healing allright and you don't think you need vaseline, just stop it or decrease the use of it,ok? Usually if it leaves a scar ...it'll be pink for a few months and then gets darker in color,...trying to take the skin's colour...then by years...it might disapper.  I hope I've answered your questions,keep up the good work:-)   Best regards,

author: lbauer  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Feb 13, 2006 1:24 pm
title: Post subject: Topical ointments - any correlation to breast
content: Hello, After reading through the email thread regarding to topical ointments and any link to cancer, I'm struck that no mention of toxins or risks came up about Petrolatum and Mineral Oil.  I've recently being researching the exact topic and believe there is plenty of evidence to suggest that in fact, there is a link. I've posted an article below and hope that it helps in the future when providing suggestions, guidance and on line feedback: Petroleum by-product that coats the skin like plastic, clogging the pores. Interferes with skin's ability to eliminate toxins, promoting acne and other disorders. Slows down skin function and cell development, resulting in premature aging. Used in many products (baby oil is 100% mineral oil!) Any mineral oil derivative can be contaminated with cancer causing PAH's (Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons). Manufacturers use petrolatum because it is unbelievably cheap.  Mineral oil    Liquidum paraffinum (also known as posh mineral oil!)    Paraffin oil    Paraffin wax    Petrolatum   Among the studies linking the petrolatum impurity PAHs to breast cancer is a Columbia University study in which researchers found that the breast tissue of women with breast cancer was 2.6 times more likely to contain elevated levels of PAHs bound to DNA (called DNA adducts) than the breast tissue of women without breast cancer (Rundle et al. 2000). The National Toxicology Programs finds that some PAHs are reasonable anticipated to be human carcinogens, and the State of California lists a number of PAHs as carcinogens in its Proposition 65 program (NTP 2002, OEHHA 2004).  Petrolatum is listed as a probable human carcinogen in the European Union's Dangerous Substances Directive (UNECE 2004), and its use in cosmetics will be banned by September 2004 with the following caveat:

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello ljen, Fibrocystic changes occur in women most often of reproductive age. However, a physical examination would identify if the areas are of a fibrocystic nature and if there is a question regarding the etiology other diagnostics (depending on your age) may include an ultrasound, mammogram, etc. Any breast abnormalities including an areolar rash that persists for a two week period warrants an investigation by a physician. I strongly encourage you to make an appointment and have this evaluated. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: CDS  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jan 26, 2006 7:25 am Location: Spain
title: Diagnosed in Spain
content: I was dx March 2004 with a 9 x 7cm tumor in my right breast. Lobular infiltrante carcinoma. My first report also said T4 Nx Mx, the oncologist told me I was stage 111b. I had 3 cycles of epirrubicina & ciclofosfamida followed by 6 cycles of taxol & gencitabina. I was on a clinical trial and had treatment every 2 weeks. Four weeks after chemo I had a mastectomy, the report said that the tumor was 7.5cm diameter, grade one with 3 out of 12 nodes cancerous. RE(+) RP(+) and HER2 (-) Next I had 25 rounds of radiotherapy about 6 weeks after the surgey. I was put on tamoxifen which I have been taking since September 2004. I return every 6 months for blood tests, chest xrays, mamogram and ´manual´checkup with the oncologist. I am 50 next month, March, female with no breast cancer history in my family. Even though I am almost 2 years from diagnosis I am still not understanding the jargon, like what regime the chemo was, I often see abbreviated stuff but don´t know what mine is. My main problem or question is: How bad/good is this prognosis. When I first started out on this journey I had an excellent english speaking onc who was brilliant but only explained bare facts and told me that the above ´package´was what I was having, I wasn´t given a choice, I also read that people are given a choice. Now when I go back for check ups I get any available onc, they say I am cured? From what I read a reoccurance is more than likely. I really need to know what I have been through and maybe what I am likely to go through, can you give me an idea please.
posted_time: Post  by CDS » Thu Jan 26, 2006 7:53 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  It would be difficult to assess the absolute risk of recurrence in your case. Please note however, that one of the most favorable factors in your case is the fact that two years have passed without recurrence. Most recurrences are known to develop in the first two years after initial treatment.  Let me try my best to discuss a few independent aspects of your prognosis.   According to your stage, stage IIIB disease is associated with a 44% 5- year survival rate when given multimodality therapy such as the one you received. Meaning, in clinical studies a little less than half the patients that took treatment were still alive 5 years after the start of their treatment plan.  As regards your pathology invasive lobular carcinoma is associated with both synchronous and metachronous contralateral primary tumors in 30% of the cases.  Lymph node positivity is associated with a less favorable prognosis. However, the highest risk of disease progression was found in patients who initially had more than 4 lymph nodes harboring the disease. So in your case, you are not doing too bad there.  When it comes to the tumor size, large tumors such as yours are also a risk factor for recurrence.  On the other hand a negative Her-2/neu is associated with much better prognosis than those who are HER-2 positive.  The strong positivity of your ER and PR receptors confers excellent prognosis and allows you to benefit from adjuvant therapy in the form of tamoxifen.  As you can see it would be difficult to give you an absolute assessment, however please bear in mind that oncologists tend to breathe easier once two years have passed with no breast cancer related events.  If you have any further questions please do not hesitate to ask.  Best regards.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Fri Jan 27, 2006 6:35 am

content: Hello,  You should have it checked immediately.   The axillary lymph nodes are located in the axillae (arm pits). They drain the arm, thoracic wall, breast. author: Prudence  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Dec 01, 2005 7:27 pm Location: Florida
title: Recurrence of invasive breast cancer
content: I am 51 years old and have just been diagnosed with breast cancer for the third time.  My history is DCIS in 1994-lumpectomy w/radiation.  Recurrence in 1999-DCIS and invasive, mastectomy w/tram flap reconstruction and chemo (adriamycin and cytoxan).  Completed only 2 of the 4 scheduled chemo sessions due to malfunction of port which resulted in severe DVT-scarring and damage to subclavian vein, complete obstruction of (L) jugular vein and partial obstruction of sagittal sinus vein.  I have been on Coumadin since this damage, with no clots and no signs of TIA or stroke.  Now, six years later, the cancer has reappeared in the tram flap and it is 90 % invasive, HER2+, ER+ and PR+, lympho-vascular invasive.  My doctors are recommending a regimen of Taxotere and Carboplatin with Herceptin, before surgery, then Herceptin for 1 year.  If a port can be put in safely, will this regimen increase my risk for more vascular damage?  I can't find any information that states that these chemo drugs will have that potential.   Do you have suggestions for alternate therapies that I might ask my doctors about?  Thank you.
posted_time: Post  by Prudence » Thu Dec 01, 2005 7:45 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope your chemotherapy is going well.   The regimen you are refering to TCH (Taxotere, Carboplatin, and Herceptin).  Although both Herceptin and Taxotere have been associated with an increased incidence of thrombovascular disorders in post-marketing reports, the incidence of this side effect is not known.  The best way to evaluate the toxicity of a given regimen would be to look at the reported toxicities in the clinical study conducted for the regimen as a whole. In this case this was In a multicenter phase II trial of docetaxel, carboplatin / cisplatin, and trastuzumab (TCH) given to HER2-positive advanced breast cancer.[1]  The overall responses were observed in 60% of those receiving carboplatin. Median time to progression was 13 months for those receiving the carboplatin regimen.[1]  Toxicities were mainly hematologic in the carboplatin regimen in the form of grade III and IV thrombocytopenia, neutropenia (with or without fever).[1]  You would need close monitoring and may need to be changed from warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as Enoxaparin 1.5 mg/kg per day.  Warfarin is associated with a high bleeding rate in patients with venous thromboembolism and cancer.[2] LMWH is as effective and safer than warfarin for secondary prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism in patients with cancer. In one study it was observed that six deaths owing to hemorrhage were noted in the warfarin group with none in the enoxaparin group. [2]  References: ========== 1. Pegram MD, Pienkowski T, Northfelt DW, Eiermann W, Patel R, Fumoleau P, et al. Results of two open-label, multicenter phase II studies of docetaxel, platinum salts, and trastuzumab in HER2-positive advanced breast cancer. J Natl Cancer Inst 2004;96:759–69. 2. Meyer G, Marjanovic Z, Valcke J, Lorcerie B, Gruel Y, Solal-Celigny P, et al. Comparison of low-molecular-weight heparin and warfarin for the secondary prevention of venous thromboembolism in patients with cancer: a randomized controlled study. Arch Intern Med. 2002;162:1729-35.

author: angel2close  Guest Posts: 37 Joined: Fri Apr 08, 2005 4:53 pm Location: Arkansas
title: [no title]
content: You may simply have a "deep bruise". When one is hit hard, a bruise can go deep into the tissues. You may not "see" a bruise but feel a lump in the area where the bruise was. It can take months for one of these to heal.  Male breast cancer is rare and I would think that with the history of being injured that a bruise would be more likely. If concerned, give it a month or so and then check with your physician if the lump has changed, other than having shown signs of healing.  Take care and let us hear back from you.

title: Painful under arm swelling
content: I am a 32 year old female with no known health problems, I do not take any medications or  birthcontrol,  and I have a generaly healthy lifstyle. 3 days ago I woke up with what felt like a bruised arm pit, but there seemed to be no bruises and no "hard pea sized lump".  the next day it was a bit swollen with no discoloration.  Today it really hurts and there is a walnut size lump... a softer fluid swelling that is covering  the source of the  pain that comes from the deepest part of the "pit" and then is tender around to the side edge of my breast.  Not only is it tender to touch, but it hurts just to have my arm down in the normal postion and I can feel the swollen lump pushing against the inside on my arm.  Within the last few hours my right under arm has become "pitless".  This is not an ingrown hair or anything like that... its deep inside.  Maybe an infection?  Today I was exhausted like I would be if I had the flu.... especially in the afternoon.  Should I be concerned?  I just moved to a new city/state and haven't been to a doctor in years.  I'm not even sure where to start or what kind of doctor I should contact or see.  Please help.
posted_time: Post  by alvorada » Wed Nov 30, 2005 1:52 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello alvorada, Thank you for using The Doctor's Lounge. Assuming that this is an axillary lymph node swelling, the lymph nodes of the axilla are known to drain the arm, thoracic wall and breast. Therefore, inflammation, infections as well as cancer will drain to this lymph group. Examples of conditions that could cause this are: Infections, cat-scratch disease, lymphoma, breast cancer, silicone implants, brucellosis, melanoma. In your case the presence of pain and tenderness as well as another swelling related to the breast favour the diagnosis of inflammatory or infectious diseases as opposed to malignancy.  I recommend that you get evaluated as soon as possible by a physician (a family doctor, GP or a surgeon would all do). Your doctor will examine your lymph node and would probably investigate the swelling in your breast possibly requesting a mammogram. You are likely to require a course of antibiotics and if a breast abscess is found it may require drainage. Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Nov 30, 2005 5:20 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: jaykay515, Thank you for your kind words. I think it is a good sign and that the nurse's argument is credible. Regarding pain/tenderness in an enlarged lymph node let me refer you to the only reliable population-based trial that was conducted to evaluate the clinical presentation and character and causes of unexplained lymph node enlargement.  In this Dutch trial it was found that pain in a lymph node can result when a lymph node rapidly increases in size, its capsule stretches and causes pain. Pain was usually the result of an inflammatory process or suppuration, but pain was also the result of hemorrhage into the necrotic center of a malignant node. The presence or absence of pain/tenderness was not found to be a reliable way to differentiate benign from malignant nodes.[1] Please let me know when the results of your biopsy are out. Best regards.  References: ========== 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: jaykay515, We are really jumping ahead of things here. The presence of a lymph node enlargement on the same side as the breast cancer as opposed to its presence on the opposite side will not help us determine its likelyhood of being cancer vs. infection.  If however, it turns out that it is a cancerous lymph node and that this is the only location where the disease is present then this is a good sign because it means that the recurrence is localized and has not spread outside the initial location to a distant location (opposite side). Such cases where the cancer has spread distantly are considered metastatic (stage IV) disease. Let's take it one step at a time. I understand your anxiety, but the only thing that can make you feel better now is hopefully the result of the biopsy. Any other information won't help at this stage.  Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat Dec 10, 2005 6:38 pm

title: Doctor Found a lump but I am only 20.
content: I went for my yearly checkup and my doctor found a lump in my breast. There is no history of breast cancer in my family and I am only 20 years old. She said that it may go away after my next period but it has not. Should I be concerned and have it checked out even though my doctor did not seemed concerned?
posted_time: Post  by youngone » Thu Oct 20, 2005 8:22 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi youngone, Fibrocystic breast changes (benign) may affect women of any age but commonly affect women during childbearing years. Typical symptoms may be areas of tenderness, lumpiness or cysts that become more tender just prior to the menstrual cycle. The texture of a cyst is somewhat different from other breast anomalies. There is research that may prove an association between fibrocystic breast changes and breast cancer not because of the cyst's themselves but the possibility of these changes obscuring identification of a suspicious lesion. Risk factors are also taken into consideration during an evaluation. This most likely is the reason that your physician was not concerned at that point but you may want to inform your physician that the "cyst" is still present and at that time, she may elect to order an ultrasound to evaluate the area. Women in their 20's-30's have breasts that are significantly more dense  than older women, so a mammogram would be of limited value. Again, contact your physiican and alert her that the area is still present and causing concern. Sincerely, Rntdj
posted_time: Post  by Theresa Jones, RN » Sun Oct 23, 2005 10:06 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Nicjean, I am glad to hear that your physician is being cautious due to your family history. It would be an impossibility to state whether or not cancer is present. However, cysts (fluid filled or solid) are not an uncommon finding in younger women and although of course, warrants an investigation, they often turn out to be of a benign nature. The ultrasound is not a painful procedure and is a diagnostic tool used especially in younger women to detect breast changes. Mammograms are typically not definitive in diagnosis because the density of the breast obscures specific findings. Good Luck with your diagnostics and I hope if your time permits you will consider posting an update. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: It could be a lipoma, although they are usually soft and moveable.  They are not dangerous, only unsightly and can be bothersome depending upon where they develop.  Lymph glands tend to be firm to hard and not moveable. Swollen lymph glands with active infection tend to be painful.  Sometimes they remain pronounced after an infection has resolved and are usually very solid to the touch.    Just to be on the cautious side, you should take doctor #3's advice and see a surgeon just to rule out anything more serious.  Of course, these are suggestions, no one can accurately diagnose this without a thorough examination.  Your shoulder pain is probably not related.  Shoulder pain is very common with any type of neck pain/strain which can happen with stress and/or degenerative joint disease and of course a tendon strain of some sort.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello David!  A lump in the male breast need not always invite fear. Malignancy or cancer in the male breast is relatively rare compared to gynecomastia (the diffuse enlargement of the breast). How long have you been having this lump? Has it always been painful? Has it grown slow/fast since notice? Is there any discharge?  In approximately 30% of males with breast cancer, family history is positive for the disease. A history of testicular trauma could also increase the risk for breast cancer. A male breast cancer typically presents as a painless mass behind the areola ('that darken area'). This is yet another pointer towards a benign diagnosis like an abscess caused by infection or fat necrosis due to lack of blood supply to the fat tissue in the breast, or gynecomastia due to other causes like drugs or hormonal imbalance or tumors.  The key to the diagnosis is an FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology) where the cells from the lump are taken out using a needle and examined under the microscope to verify the exact kind of cells making up the lump. If such examination does not clarify the cause, one would require a biopsy, which takes a little tissue from the lump to be examined.  The presence of lumps (lymph nodes) in the right arm pit could pronounce a graver predicament. In any case, a visit to the surgeon should be the next step. And I assure you nobody with a lump in his/her breasts would take it as a joke, and as for males to worry about it would be a waste.  I hope this helps.  Bill

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: breast cancer
content: Hello,   The nickel-like hard disks are a normal finding for guys and are referred to as adolescent gynecomastia. It usually develops around puberty; it is sore to touch, can happen in one or both sides and can get fat deposits around them. The breast tissues are very sensitive to estrogen and testosterone in the blood and at puberty a boys testosterone levels will rise and fall drastically causing the breast tissue to be stimulated to grow and respond to estrogen in the blood, all men have a little bit of estrogen. At the end of the teen years, if the breasts are still swollen it is usually because the tissues have remained hypersensitive to the tiny amounts of estrogen in the blood. Hormone therapy, body building drugs, steroids can also cause this to happen. Your Physician can do blood work and check your hormone levels and I would agree that you should have it checked out. There aren’t any real side-effects to the removal of the lumps that I can find; your Surgeon would be more knowledgeable by far.   According to the American Cancer Society, less than 1% of all breast carcinomas occur in men. There are familial tendencies for developing breast cancer in men who have a number of female relatives with breast cancer or who have had the gene BRCA2 (Breast Cancer 2) gene mutation identified in the family.

title: Itchy nipple
content: I am 37 years old and when I was pregnant with my now 6 year old son, I developed an itchy area on the aureola of my left breast.  The itching was so bad that I would scratch it until my entire breast turned red.  I ignored it at the time, because it did not itch all the time.  About a year ago, I had scratched it so bad that it scabbed up.  It did not bleed, but it looked like a very dry patch of skin.  I had my regular OB/GYN visit and my Doctor looked at it and suggested I visit my dermatologist, which I did.  She told me it was excema and recommended some over the counter lotion.  It helps on occasion, but it still itches at times.  The "dry" patch is gone.   I was also unable to breast feed because my son could not latch on to that same nipple.  In the same breast, I had a tender area that seemed to linger.  When I had my annual OB/GYN appointment this year, she recommended a diagnostic mammogram.  The radiologist did not see anything that suggested cancer and that all was clear, though my breasts are very dense.  I have heard about a disease called Padget's Disease of the nipple, which is a form of cancer.  I am under the impression that it is very rare.    It hasn't gotten worse over the years and I don't see any major changes in my breast, nipple or areola. Could this itching be an early form of that disease or just like my dermatologist stated, excema?  Thanks

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi there, Paget's disease accounts for about 3% of breast cancer cases so it is as you say a rare entity. It presents with a clinical picture very similar to eczema but unlike eczema it does not respond to eczema treatment. From your description I understand that you do not have any manifestations of eczema but are only complaining of itching and tenderness in the area of the nipple. In my opinion that does not represent an early manifestion of breast cancer. Please since this is a clinical question refer to your physician who can obviously assess your condition whereas I cannot.  If you are over 40 years old then you should do a mammogram and get a breast examination every 1-2 years according to current recommendations. If you have a family history or other risk factors for developing breast cancer then you should start your annual examinations at an earlier age. Have a look at our breast cancer pathology page which contains a section on Paget's disease.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Aug 15, 2005 8:03 am

content: Dear pinkribbonjen,  The very classic regimen is 6 FEC  or FAC + radiotherapy sessions.... but i guess he recommends adding taxol in case of micro metastasis. IDC is aggressive and i am surprised they haven't removedthe whole breast. BUt it's small...and since there are no positive lymph nodes and they have removed it all then a lumpectomy is certainly better phsycologically than removing the whole breast.  It's a good plan...,new one , so you won't find a lot of papers about it. And it's as efficient if you tolerated the taxol.  Good luck,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Yes I agree with Dr. Wafaa.  The study you are referring to is the PACS 01 trial the results of which were published in December 2004. FAC and FEC regimens were considered standard treatment long before AC --> Taxol and they are both valid regimens till today. More and more results are coming in favour of using taxanes in the adjuvant setting. So it seems wiser to compare a new line of treatment to the more established regimen (FEC, FAC).  You should also not PinkRibbonJen, that FAC is exactly the same as AC with the addition of 5-Floururacil (the 'F'). FEC replaces the A (Adriamycin) with E (Epirubicin) an analogue of adriamycin produced by the same company which they claim is safer to the heart and thus larger doses are given.  Another point which Dr. Wafaa brought up: since you have opted for a breast conservation surgery, which is a perfectly valid option, have you taken radiotherapy to the breast? Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Mon Aug 15, 2005 5:13 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello FaithAnn, I think you should get an examination. There are many benign conditions that can cause bleeding from the nipple so it may be nothing to worry about. In that case it could be hormonal, a benign growth (duct papilloma). Generally, the time to worry about nipple discharge is when it’s spontaneous (comes out by itself without squeezing), keeps on happening,is only on one side, and/or if it is clear and sticky, like an egg white, or bloody. If these symptoms are present a doctor should check you.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Tiffany, Fibrocystic changes, Fibroadenomas, may sometimes arise from connective or glandular tissue of the breast and are usually benign. However, a lateral mammogram (single view) in my opinion is not sufficient and two views should have been completed. A negative mammogram result is not sufficient in evaluating a breast lump. Generally a diagnosis requires a biopsy. I would suggest you talk to your physician, inquire why only a lateral mammogram view was done for an evaluation, and ask about a biopsy. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: It depends on several other issues as well not least of which is the tumor size. If tumor was very small or if the pathology is carcinoma in situ then adjuvant hormonal treatment may be sufficient. However, in most cases adjuvant chemotherapy followed by hormonal therapy is the standard line of treatment.

title: [no title]
content: Hi jennifersut, First you may want to perform a pregnancy test to definitely rule out pregnancy. With this being ruled out, other condition that may cause a milky discharge are hormonal imbalances, pituitary gland disorders, underactive thyroid, etc. I would certainly suggest a breast evaluation (especially with the noticed difference in size as well as the discharge) to identify the causative factor. Call you physicians office, explain your symptoms, and get an evaluation. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: soonerchick58  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Mar 28, 2005 2:40 pm Location: Tulsa, OK
title: Thigh Weakness
content: I am a 46 yr old female who was diagnosed with Stage III A Breast Cancer in August of 2004. I had a Masectomy in August as well and began 16 weeks of Chemo in September 2004. The first round of Cehmo was FEC, and the second was Gemzar and Taxol. I experienced severe thigh and knee pain with the Gemzar and Taxol and was taken off after my third treatment, jan. 2004 because it was too strong. I now have sever thigh weakness, and have difficulty getting in and out of chairs as well as climbing stairs. The severe pain I experienced with the Chemo went away after two weeks once the Chemo ended, but the weakness returned three weeks ago. My Oncologist is perplexed and my Neurologist is trying to find out what the cause is. Are you familiar with this, and what could be the cause?
posted_time: Post  by soonerchick58 » Mon Mar 28, 2005 2:48 pm

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Deborah,  So sorry to hear about your problems, I was just wondering...why were you put on Gemzar and Taxol after finishing FEC? have you had recurrent cancer(relapse) anywhere or in the other breast? have you had your tumor checked for ER and PR (hormone receptors)? if yes, are they positive or negative?  I think you should ask for a bone scan...when was the last work up done for you...including a bone scan,chest X-ray, abdominal ultrasound or CT scan?!  have you had your menopause already?! because these might be as simple as post-menopausal or perimenopausal symptoms.  Best regards,

author: soonerchick58  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Mar 28, 2005 2:40 pm Location: Tulsa, OK
title: Reply to Dr. Hadi
content: Ye, I had the Gemzar and Taxol after the FEC. These symptons didn't start until 3 months after all my Chemo was completed. My CPK came back at 5000. From what I understand, a normal CPK is 0-140.  I had a CT scan on my spine, abdomen and brain, along with a muscle biopsy which all came back negative. It is now 2 months later and my CPK's have dropped to about 450, minor weakness in my thighs, and still no answer to what led up to the problem.  Also, my cancer was hormone receptive, and I have not had any re-occurance of the cancer in either breast. I had a partial Hysterectomy done this past week, my pap as well as overies were normal. They also performed an ablation (sp) to remove the lining from my uterus, which they said was fine as well.  My Nuerologist is still waiting on biopsy they sent out of state to rule out any diseases that we hardly ever hear about.  Thanks for writing back.  Deborah

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi JayJee04, Lymph nodes are the bodies filtering system for bacteria. One of the reasons they commonly enlarge is as a result of an infection. They may not return to their pre-infectious size. Lymph nodes of the size you describe is likely due to this cause and should not cause any alarm at this point.  Sincerely, Rntdj

title: [no title]
content: Clinical data: Patient had surgery on the right breast in 1999, which was benign.  Bilateral Diagnostic Mammography: This examination was reviewed with the benefit of CAD (computer-aid detection).  Two views of the breast show extremly dense breasts with large amount of residual fibroglandular tissues with diffuse nodular pattern. This dense parenchyma of the breasts lowers the sensitivity of the test. Any palpable mass should be managed on a clinical basis.  There is no definite evidence of dominant mass, cluster of suspicious microcalifications, or any other signs of malignancy.  There are lymph nodes in both axillae.  Impression: No evidence of malignancy in the dense breasts. An untrasonography was performed on the same day.  Birads 1: Negative.  Clinical data: Followup to mammogram of the same day.  Bilateral Breast Ultrasonography: The examination reveals no evidence of discrete solid or cystic nodule.  Impression: Normal bilateral breast sonogram.  Birads 1: Negative.

author: Dr. Wafaa Abdel-Hadi  Medical Doctor Posts: 228 Joined: Mon Mar 07, 2005 2:15 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Henry710,, Thank you for writing us her clinical data  So your mother hasn't seen an oncologist yet!? ...It's really a matter of an oncologist to see her and examine her by him/herself.  The report you have sent us  is very concised, and it doesn't state how big and how many are the Lymph nodes?!  I am afraid that I cannot jugde or even give you advice on such small data. But what I can tell you is that her breast is free...as they've said in the reports.  She needs to see an oncologist to have a look and feel her lymph nodes and to read the Ultrasound report properly.  If the lymph nodes are big enough that concerns him,then he will request a simple procedure called a biopsy to see the cells under the microscope...and determine its nature (benign or malignant.....it might even be inflammatory...let's hope so):-)   about the explanations you want:- 1-"bliateral diagnostic mammography" = that's the name of teh procedure...it's like an ultrasound on the breats(mammo) and bilateral means on both breasts. 2-"examination review by CAD"...= they have explained it already!=computer aid detection...using computer skills as well in diagnosis. 3-"large amounts of residual fibroglandular tissue......etc" that's the normal tissue of the breast...just scientific names,don't worry   4-"lymph nodes in both axilae"....i understand that you don't know what a lymph node is... it's some sort of glands in the  body....responsible for clearing the body from its waste products and has a role in immunity as well....they can be enlarged in alot of cases...all peoplle think of cancer these days... but  for an example if u get a flu.. lymph nodes in your neck can get bigger....they are distributed everywhere in your body.  (As i told you ... we have to know how big they are?!how did they look like by ultrasound?!...a doctor should  really examine her  to see if she needs a biopsy or not)  5-"no evidence of malignancy in the dense breast"= no evidence of cancer in the breast (good)!  So, relax, it might be nothing...just comfort her and arrange for a meeting with an oncologist...that's all for now... tell me how it goes?  Best wishes,

author: sofsof  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Sun Mar 27, 2005 7:45 pm Location: us
title: Soy after breast cancer diagnosis - friend or foe?
content: There has been so much written about soy and breast cancer, all of it very confusing.  Some studies seem to suggest that Soy is beneficial to women with estrogen-dependant breast cancer, while others say that soy products might promote cancer cell growth.  What is the latest consensus on the subject?  All the women in my Cancer Support Group are utterly confused and frustrated, especially since many of us were told to switch to a more vegetarian (or a "fish-eterian") diet, of which tofu is often a major ingredient. Also, does Soy interfere with Tamoxifen?  Thanks in advance!
posted_time: Post  by sofsof » Sun Mar 27, 2005 7:49 pm

author: Rhonda P, CEP  Paramedic Posts: 252 Joined: Wed Mar 16, 2005 8:37 am Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Soy and Breast Cancer
content: According to the American Cancer Society, there is no clear-cut evidence on the advantages or disadvantages of increased levels of isoflavonoids in the prevention of breast cancer but they do say that the effects of phytoestrogens on women who already have breast cancer, women at risk for a recurrence of breast cancer, or those at risk for developing it because of genetic factors should avoid extra isoflavonoids because it may stimulate the growth of cells.  Flaxseed and Soy isoflavones  contains phytoestrogens which is plant estrogen and 100gm of any soy product has the estrogenic content of a contraceptive pill. Research has been done on phytoestrogen in the diet, two glasses of soy milk a day contains enough chemical to change the timing of a woman’s menstrual cycle and increase the experience of volatile emotions of PMS due to the hormonal upset.   Another finding about soy is that it can cause HYPOTHYROIDISM . Two isoflavones found in soy, genistein and daidzen are being found to cause toxicity in estrogen sensitive tissues and in the thyroid and there is also rising concern of the effects on fetuses and young infants.
posted_time: Post  by Rhonda P, CEP » Sun Mar 27, 2005 11:58 pm

author: Natasha  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed Mar 02, 2005 7:38 am Location: Florida
title: Pain-Lump concern
content: I have been experiencing pain in my left breast for about a month.  While I wasn't overly concerned at first my concern has increased as I have found a lump.  I do have fibrocysitic breasts and last year had an incident where after my mammogram I was referred to a surgeon for follow up.  He aspirated a rather large cyst then referred me to a breast specialist because I had what they called a 'cluster'.  The specialist had to make an incision as they were unable to do a needle biopsy due to the clusters tissue being so hard.  The biopsy results all came back ok. Note: the cyst I had was not at all painful, I found it doing a self-exam at which time my regular mammogram appointment was moved up so I could get in sooner.  This lump with associated pain I have now feels different and is located much deeper within the breast tissue if that makes sense even though I do not have large breasts.  The pain is pretty sharp, sometimes throbbing and I have a sensation of heaviness in the breast area where the lump is located.  The lump is fairly hard and elongated, painful if I apply any pressure to the end of it.  I am scheduled for my annual mammogram the 21st of April even though I was due for it in November of 2004 this was the first available opening.  As you will see by the requested information I filled out I have a family history of breast cancer and because of that I have been having annual mammograms since I was 25.  I was referred for genetic testing to see if I carry BRCA1 or BRCA2 however Medicare does not cover it so I couldn't have it done.  Due to all the non-covered expenses I incurred from the surgery I had in July 2004 I am already drowning in medical bills that I am desperately trying to get paid off so I am hesitant to call and schedule an appointment with my Dr. as it is now 2005 I will get hit with my yearly deductible right away.  Does this sound like cause for concern where I should contact my Dr. before my mammogram or am I just being paranoid because of my family history?  While the thought on incurring yet more bills that will literally take me years to pay off is horrifying, I don't want to jeopardize my life either.  My apologies if my post is to long winded, I just thought the more information I could provide the better.  Thank you for your time:) Natasha

title: HRT and various breast cancer
content: I was on HRT for almost 5 years. Nov. 2001 was diagnosed with angiosarcoma of breast & had mastectomy, no other treatment. My doctors said no need to stop HRT. About 8-9 mos. ago, I again had concerns & asked about the estrogen patch instead & my dr. said due to liver problems (Hep.C & 2 hemangiomas) the patch would be less intrusive, so I switched. After all the new HRT findings, in Aug.2002 I stopped. In Nov.2002, I had invasive carcinoma breast cancer & another mastectomy. Now they tell me I am 90% positive estrogen receptor & need Tamoxifen & should do chemo also. I am totally confused. I told Dr. I needed to research & I go back to him 1/24 & need to make decision. After putting estrogen in my body for 5 yrs., now I need Tamoxifen to block it. I am 55 yrs. old.
posted_time: Post  by Janrok3 » Sat Jan 04, 2003 6:30 am

author: JGordonMD
title: Re:
content: The recent reports of new studies looking at the risks and benefits of HRT in women who are or who have taken it are confusing. There are differing results from different studies. There may indeed be a small risk of developing breast cancer is a woman is taking HRT. However, women who are not or who have not taken HRT or birth control pills can still develop a hormon receptor-positive breast cancer. If a breast cancer is identifies and if it is found to be hormone receptor-positive, then a standard recommendation is for a woman to stop taking the HRT (unless she is enrolled onto a study evaluating if it needs to be stopped or continued even when tamoxifen is used). Part of the treatment for such a breast cancer would be to consider the use of tamoxifen (which blocks the action of estrogen at the level of the breast cancer cell) or arimidex (which blocks the production of estrogen in the body). In such cases, independent or any surgery or chemotherapy, hormone therapy with tamoxifen can provide significant benefit.
posted_time: Post  by JGordonMD » Sat Jan 04, 2003 6:30 am

author: Dr. Brim M.  Medical Doctor Posts: 16 Joined: Thu Dec 23, 2004 2:32 am Location: Birmingham, AL
title: [no title]
content: Janrok: HRT is believed to increase the risk of developing breast cancer.  It is also believed to increase the risk of relapse if you've had breast cancer in the past, particularly in ER+ tumors.  Tamoxifen blocks the effects of estrogen and progesterone on hormone receptors in cancer cells.  It has been shown in large trials to increase the survival of patients with breast cancer.  Skenz: Until new data matures, HRT is contraindicated in anyone with a history of breast cancer, ER positive or negative.  There is no evidence that removing your ovaries will keep your cancer from coming back.

title: Breast tissue or lump? how do you tell the difference?
content: How can you tell the difference between breast tissue/fat and a lump that should be looked at by a doctor?  Tissue feels lumpy regardless, so are there certian characteristics to look for in a lump? (e.g. how close to the surface it is, hardness of it, no pain, etc) Thanks
posted_time: Post  by 3flutedpoints » Sun Jan 30, 2005 8:21 pm

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi 3flutedpoints, Breast tissue does feel somewhat irregular and "lumpy". By doing monthly self breast exams this will enable you to familiarize yourself with the different textures of tissue. Both breast usually have similar tissue textures. An extra area of tissue that you can feel in one breast and not the other would be suspicious of a lump. Sometimes they can be uncomfortable, or painful especially near menstrual cycles, which may  indicate fibrocystic tendencies and are usually benign (not cancerous) in nature. Again, it's encouraged to do monthly self breast exams, the same time each month, about a week after your cycle, so when you recognize breast tissue the feels out of the ordinary you can call your physician for an evaluation. I hope this was helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi angelseeingred, Have you had any sort of blow (injury) to the chest that you can think of? The reason I asked this is sometimes an injury can cause areas of fatty tissue to not perform their function and die off. This may generate this particular color of drainage. Generally speaking birth control pills may cause a nipple discharge but it is usually a different color than what you described. Have you noticed any lumps etc.? Any discharge from the nipple should be evaluated, in your case re-evaluated and if it isn't caused by an anomoly in the breast itself, in my opinion, lab work should be done to rule out any hormonal, or endocrine dysfunction. I encourage you to talk with your physician about this again. I hope this was helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

posted_time: Post  by cbarrett » Wed Jan 19, 2005 11:31 am

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi cbarrett, Please don't automatically assume that this is breast cancer. You will not do yourself any favors by worrying about something before you actually know the results. Among others, one of the signs of Inflammatory breast cancer is a pink, red, or dark colored area that may have  the texture of an orange. Since the area in question has not changed over several months and you have no other signs and symptoms that would immediately flag a concern for breast cancer I would be more inclined to consider first a dermatological problem. By all means keep your dermatology appointment and I also encourage you to make an appointment with your gynecologist. I assure you that you will not be laughed at. Concerns such as these warrant evaluation and it's extremely important to identify any possible problems early so they can be treated. Keep calm until your appointment and good luck to you. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Stromal Fibrosis
content: Hi, I am a 35 year old with a history of multiple breast biopsy's.  I had a fibroadenoma removed from my R Breast in 1995, stromal fibrosis removed from my R Breast (same area) in 2002, (the surgeon stated he did not remove all of the stromal fibrosis because he would have had to remove over 1/2 of my breast).  I am now presenting with a return of the stromal fibrosis in my right breast, a larger mass that it was in 2002, and a new area of thickening in my L breast. author: indigo36d  Guest Posts: 7 Joined: Fri Dec 10, 2004 11:09 pm
title: [no title]
content: Sue,  Women with benign hyperplasia of the breast or fibrocystic breast disorders have a slightly higher (20 vs 8 percent) risk for breast cancer depending on other variables particularly a family history of breast cancer .   A women with family history of breast cancer with or without stromal fibrosis or other benign disorders of the breast has an increased risk of developing breast cancer.  You might also consider asking your Dr to refer you for genetics testing and counseling. This entails gathering /evaluating with you a family health history and in particular a history of breast cancer and other malignancies in addition to some blood or tissue testing.  The most commonly monitored genetic markers indicating increased risk of breast cancer are BRCA-1 and BRCA-2.  This is an interesting website related to your concerns  Click here!  Regards, N Koch RN OCN

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Your doctor was right in stating that risk assessment for breast cancer in women aged less than 35 is not possible by the present tools, and it is of no consequence too, since breast cancer is very rare before this age. The best assessment with your personal data would place you at a 5-year risk of less than 0.7%, which would mean that chances are more than 99.3% that you will NOT be diagnosed with breast cancer in the coming 5 years. A better assessment is possible if your race is known, since some races like caucasians have been known to be at more risk for breast cancer than others.  Hope this helps.  bill

author: Dr. A. Saif  Medical Doctor Posts: 101 Joined: Mon Oct 25, 2004 1:56 pm Location: UK  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Saif       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Dear Rachel Z,  It may be that the best person to answer the question is your surgeon or oncologist.  It is difficult to be very specific to individual cases, but I can try and help, as I understand you are probably going through a very anxious time at present.  Please remember I am being very general here..  1) Breast tumours in the elderly tend to be less aggressive than in the young in general, but carcinomas do progress, unless treated.  Hopefully you will have been monitored frequently since your last tumour diagnosis and therefore your tumour has been caught early enough for treatment.    2) Whether you have had your maximum allowable dose or not can only be determined by your raditherapist, but I would assume that there is still room for further treatment to your Right breast.  3) The treatment options for your latest tumour is not confined just to radiotherapy, and again this ought to be discussed with your specialist.  Regards,  Saif

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for your post to The Doctor's Lounge.  I am limited in responding fully to your question since I do not have the opportunity to see the mammograms.  It would be helpful to have the mammograms compared to prior ones to see if the changes noted represent a new or an old finding.  If the mammogram finding was not identified on the ultrasound, then it may not be a cancerous fidning.  However, this does not remove the possibility of a cancer.  Calcifications can be seen with various malignant and non-malignant breast findings, but some cancers and non-cancerous findings can be present withour calcifications present.  There are two approaches:  obtaining a biopsy now of the reported mammogram area or repeating the mammogram in 6 months and if the findings persist or change, then doing a biopsy then.  Such a decision needs to be done after talking with your Mother's family doctor.  In many cases, it is not unreasonable to wait for a follow-up mammogram.  However, again, such a decision needs to be reached after talking about it fully with the family doctor and understanding the pluses and minuses of either approach.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Breast lump
content: Lumps or cysts in a breast are more likely to be benign as opposed to malignant.  However, any lump in a breast (including in men) should be evaluated.  Men develop breast cancer at a much lower incidence than women, approximately 1 case of male breast cancer for every 100 cases of remale breast cancer.  Again, most findings in a breast are benign.  It is better to have a breast finding evaluated and find out that it is not a cancer than to assume otherwise and miss a cancer if such were to be present.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Chemotherapy is known to be very toxic. In determining the dose of a particular drug the side effects of the drug are the limiting factor. In most drugs the relationship between the dose of the drug and the side effects is linear. In the case of carboplatin the effect is also dose dependent, but as shown by Egorin and Calvert, the effect is most closely related to the drug exposure in an individual as measured by the area under the curve that plots the carboplatin plasma concentration against time (Area under the curve).   Both groups derived formulas to predict toxicity. In the Calvert formula it takes into account effects of renal toxicity. The glomerular filtration rate is measured directly with labeled EDTA. Chatelut's formula uses creatinine clearance (easier to calculate) which is not as accurate as the Calvert formula but still superior to conventional dosing.   The forumula has been widely individualized. Patients who are elderly or have a poor performance status have a higer risk of toxicity hence some formulas take into account age as well.  To examine the actual formula for the area under the curve see this page.  Click here!  The recommended dosage of carboplatin in previously untreated patients with a normal renal function is 400 mg/m². Usually the carboplatin dosage is calculated using the target area under the free carboplatin plasma concentration versus time curve (AUC) and the pre-treatment glomerular filtration rate (GFR):  dose (mg) = target AUC x (GFR + 25)  A target AUC of 5 approximates 400 mg/m²

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for your question to The Doctor's Lounge.  First: unfortunately, common medical problems can occur in the same person just due to the problems being common and not necessarily related to each other.  Many things found on mammograms turn out not to be cancerous.  I hope that is the case for you!  Second: CLL can sometimes cause lymph node masses to appear.  Although there are lymph nodes in the breast that can be seen on mammogram, I am not aware of any significant relationship between an early stage CLL that is being watched and lymph node problems in the breast.  I am also not aware of any specific increased risk of patients with CLL developing breast cancer.  Breast cancer is more common than CLL.  There may be a relationship between the two of which I am not aware.  Third: breast cancer cells, if present, are not the same cells as the abnormal lymphocytes that make up CLL.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

author: adolfo_fa  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Feb 07, 2004 2:53 am Location: Mexico City
title: Comment
content: Hi, Your description of symptoms sounds like something named Mondor's disease. This is an inflamation of the venous vessels on the skin of the body, most frequently breast skin. Is most frequently related to infection or trauma, sometimes unknown trauma (like a shot on the breast when you are sleeping), and in few cases is related to cancer. The most common reasons are benign. Don't worry extremely, but will be useful to look for a doctor to confirm this diagnosis. Regards,  Adolfo Fuentes, MD

That, several hours later, went away and left a sore kind of feelin inside my abdomen.  This morning I woke up and my entire back and abdomen felt like it was on fire until I got up and moved around a bit and relieved myself. author: adolfo_fa  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Feb 07, 2004 2:53 am Location: Mexico City
title: Comment.
content: Hi, I'm a surgical onclogist in Mexico City and my development area is breast cancer. The symptoms that you have are named postmastectomy neuritis. Even when your surgeon didn't remove all the lymph nodes the approach to axilla sometimes induces this kind of result. In that case you need only an antineuritic, which will be since something so simple as vitamin B12. The abdominal symptoms sound me like spastic colitis. I will suggest you to look your doctor for a prokinetic drug to give you a better movement on your bowel. If is necessary, stool tests will be useful. None of the symptoms are related commonly to metastatic disease. Don't worry about it. Sometimes the start of a symptom induces a stress response like colitis. Regards,  Adolfo Fuentes, MD

Cysts and lumps are pretty common in my family. Also if it could be the nipple ring how long will it take before I'll notice it getting smaller?  Thanks.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Lumps in the breasts need evaluation, if or not they arose after piercing the nipple. There has been incidences where partial removal of breast has had to be done for what began as an infection which went on to become breast abscess. This mandates a thorough investigation to be on the safer side, where most people who have had their body parts pierced live a normal life. I suggest you find the definitive diagnosis of the lump by means of cytology or biopsy, which your surgeon would probably explain in detail.  The risks in nipple piercing are obviously under-documented and may be as high as 10-20% in the months after the procedure. Healing of the wound channel can take 6-12 months.  Nipple piercing has grown in popularity within the last years and is in general not a stigma of a subculture or lower social classes any more. However, the risk for breast infection is on the one hand underestimated by the women and on the other hand played down by piercing studios. Breast infection after nipple piercing is rarely documented in scientific literature and data bases. Only seven case reports are scientifically published so far.   Insufficient understanding as well as inconsequent performance of hygienic preparation of the wound beneath other risk factors like nicotine abuse, wrong size of jewelry, post breast enlargement with prosthesis etc. increase the risk of breast infection after nipple piercing. Last year, doctors in Germany published regarding the obvious underestimated health problems of this fashion phenomenon. Their study constituted the largest series of breast infection after nipple piercing in the world.  An observer of today's fashion for facial piercings might think that only the young and extrovert or those interested in extreme sexual behaviour get pierced.   A survey of 134 pierced readers of Body Art magazine revealed that 79% were aged 29 or over and 58% were married or in a long-term relationship. Less than 20% saw themselves as masochistic, sadistic, fetishist, exhibitionists, or narcissistic, and little more than half thought themselves adventurous.  Even its most enthusiastic devotees find piercing's appeal difficult to explain, but that's just as true of pot holing, golf, crosswords, and train spotting. I know I have gone laterally over the topic at hand, but I hope it helps to confront some of the assumptions we might have.  Hope this helps  - Bill

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  I thought I might as well rob some of the praises for dr Tamer Fouad !  Nipple discharge is most commonly associated with hormonal (endocrine) alterations and/or medications, when changes are often bilateral.  The most common cause of clinically significant discharge is growth within the tubes coming out of the milk glands (intraductal growth), due to benign overgrowth of cells within the milk glands (hyperplasia), proliferation of projections from the cells lining the tubes (micropapillary proliferation), benign growths (solitary papillomas), and/or cancer (ductal carcinoma).  Most patients have surgically reversible, nonsignificant nipple discharge.  Non–clinically significant nipple discharge more commonly occurs in women using contraceptives. Non–clinically significant nipple discharge also occurs in women who are taking medications that have estrogen-like effects on the breast epithelium.  The most common types of nipple discharge are bilateral, emanate from several ducts in the same nipple, and vary in color from white to brown. To be clinically significant, nipple discharge must be true, spontaneous, persistent, and nonlactational. Surgically significant discharge is clear (ie, watery), serous (ie, clear yellow), serosanguineous, or sanguineous (ie, bloody).   The likelihood of malignancy increases when the discharge is unilateral and arises from a single duct, when it is accompanied by a palpable mass, when it is associated with a positive mammographic or galactographic finding and a positive cytologic result (examination of cells under the microscope), or when the patient is older than 50 years.   Mammography is the evaluation of the breast by means of X-rays. Galactography or ductography is mammography after a dye is injected into the breasts.  Clinically significant nipple discharge is most commonly secondary to intraductal growths, ranging from hyperplasias (benign cell overgrowths) to malignancies. Researchers have reported that when clinical, cytologic, and breast imaging findings show no evidence of malignancy, nipple discharge spontaneously resolves in as many as 73% of patients within 5 years.   Mammography, although typically unrevealing, is the first examination that should be performed in a patient with clinically significant nipple discharge.  Subsequent to negative mammographic findings, galactography or ductography is the procedure of choice. Galactography involves the retrograde injection of water-soluble radiopaque contrast material into a discharging duct with subsequent mammographic imaging.  Galactography is not indicated unless the nipple discharge is spontaneous, unilateral, and expressed from a single pore.  I suggest it best for your wife to visit the surgeon. And there is no substitute for direct clinical examination.  I hope this helps.  Warm regards,  - Bill

posted_time: Post  by Guest » Mon May 26, 2003 7:54 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: Genital herpes and chemotherapy
content: Although chemotherapy is known to decrease the body's immune system and may exacerbate the herpes, the importance of chemotherapy here outways the danger from genital herpes. The herpes should be treated aggressively with either acyclovir or famcyclovir while the chemo is taken so long as your blood counts allow it.
