author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: KC and Tony,  Could you provide me with more information about your prior breast surgeries?  Were formal breast cancers found in the breats or were non-malignant breast cancer changes identified?  Having such information would be very helpful in better understanding the overall picture of your current breast findings.  Stromal fibrosis or other terminology to describe various characterisitics of non-malignant breast findings is not in and of itself a precancerous lesion and does not in and of itself turn into a cancer.  There are several breast tissue changes that are not formal breast cancers, but do increase the risk of a woman developing a breast cancer compared to a woman without such findings in the breast.  These changes include atypical ductal hyperplasia, ductal carcinoma in situ, and lobular carcinoma in situ.  Did any of your prior breast surgeries identify these features?  I do understand your concern about undergoing another breast surgery.  It can be difficult on breast examination or standard mammogram to identify what is a cancer and what is not.  That is why biopsies or surgeries are done, even though sometimes no cancer is found.  However, if any of the above mentioned non-malignant breast abnormalities are found, then there may be the potential for using Tamoxifen to decrease the risk of a true breast cancer developing.  I would recommend undergoing an ultrasound and a fine needle aspiration or needle biopsy.  Based upon those results, then further Medical Oncology evaluation would be in order.  If no cancer is identified, then one may consider a digital mammogram for better resolution or an MRI of the breast.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Breast cancer
content: I would recommend that in addition to talking further with your surgeon about surgery, you should seek the advice of a Medical Oncologist who is experienced with breast diseases.  It sounds like, based upon what you post, that the prior breast findings were not malignant.  Fibrocystic disease does not in and of itself become cancer.  It is a common finding and can make the reading of a mammogram difficult because it can look like a cancer.  Thus why biopsies and surgeries are done, but I understand yoru concern about undergoing another surgery.  One may consider a different way to image the breast, such as MRI.

My tumor is HR neg. which in simple terms means it is not hormone produced, but cell produced.   I have a 75% chance of reoccurance and matasticise to other organs.  My doctor are also not sure if they were able to get all the cancer.  Also as a result fo the fact I have been diagnosed so young in life, my doctors have asked me to make sure I notify all family members, as cancer is a genetic thing.[/i]"   :arrow: You just read portions of an email I recently received  from my sister. :cry:   I don't understand all her wording, as I have been unable to locate very little of this anywhere on the web.. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: HR (ER) negative Breast cancer with lymph node metastasis
content: Dear Dolphindancer, When a normal cell turns malignant it loses many of the characteristics of its normal coutnerpart. Grade 2 to 3 refers to the degree by which the cell has lost any resemblance to a normal breast cell. Grade 3 being the worst. So your sister would be in the middle range there. Staging of breast cancer is another thing altogether that describes the extent to which a cancer has spread in the body. Stage I: it hasnt spread. Stage IV: It has spread to distant organs.  I truely cannot tell the stage of your sisters disease from the information you have given but she has lymph node involvement which means she would be either stage II/III. Breast cancer cells were found to be two types those that responde to anti-hormonal treatment (which is a convenient and effective type of treatment) and those that do not repsond to this type of treatment (i.e. are left with only chemotherapy as their only alternative). One major setback is the age of your sister, with younger age being a bad sign. Its also an indication of a possible genetic basis for the disease. Can you confirm that she actually had a cervical cancer or was it an ovarian cancer? Was she put on proper follow up since her first cancer? Your sister has certainly painted a very dismal picture. I wouldnt say that I am excited either about her results, but what i want to say is that every patient is a different story and that in real life many people are actually better off than what the statistical numbers tell us. Did she actually confirm the genetic basis of her disease?  You can have her consult with us if she needs any questions. Best regards, Dr. Tamer Fouad, M.D.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Breast cancer
content: Maryrose,  There has been and continues to be a lot of interest regarding dietary factors in the pathogenesis and prevention of various cancers.  Unfortunately, the epidemiology of cancer is very complicated and it is difficult to make an exact cause and effect statement about foods and dietary supplements and the development of cancer.  Regading the prevention or modification of cancer risks by using certain dietary supplements, there are active clinical research trials ongoing trying to answer this question in various cancers.  However, to date, no definitive or conclusive data has emerged and thus, aside from a healthy and well-balanced diet (which always makes good health sense), no specific diets or health supplements can be recommended to cancer patients or to the general public.
